summary: Duong Van Minh, a Major General in the Army of the Republic of Vietnam (ARVN), is portrayed in the documents as a key figure in the political instability of South Vietnam during the Diem regime. He is depicted as critical of President Diem's leadership, particularly regarding the handling of the Buddhist issue and Diem's perceived loss of popular support. Following Diem's assassination, Minh sent condolences to President Lyndon B. Johnson after President Kennedy's death, representing the people of South Vietnam.
significance: Duong Van Minh's significance in the JFK context lies in his role in the coup that led to the assassination of President Diem. The US government's involvement, or lack thereof, in this coup was a point of contention and scrutiny following Kennedy's own assassination. Minh's leadership in South Vietnam following Diem's death also had implications for the US's involvement in the Vietnam War during Johnson's presidency.
